resources:
Android Guide Hello world! Settings Help About My name is Mahboubeh Abbasi, I am in Computer Programming and Analysis Technology button provide the instruction of different Android tolls. The second button (Website) gives you the links to different Android learning website. Help About Technology Website
adb
emulator
android
screenshot2
gradle
pm
lint
project
panel
toolbar
status bar
preview pane
project explorer
.idea folder
intellisense
module
live layout
init
commit
push
add
pull
branch
clone
adb:provides a terminal-based interface for interacting with our phones file system.
emulator: it copys all the hardware and software of a typical mobile device but it can not place the actuall phone calls. Also, it provides a screen of your application.
android: gives you plenty platform for creating apps and games for Android users as well as open open market place for distributing to them.
screenshot2: you can make a file with extended .png that is the screenshot of the application you made.
gradle: is an advanced build system, means it took best features from other build systems and combined into one. Also, it is plugin based system.
pm: is a tool to perform actions on application packages installed on the device.
lint: checks your Android project source files for potential bugs and optimization improvements security, performance, etc..
project: Provides an overview of the project file structure that allows us to navigate to specific files and folders. The drop-down menu in the toolbar can be used to display the project in different ways.
panel: When designing a program, it allows us to specify the user interface by providing what information (text and pictures) will be presented to the user at different stages of using the program.
toolbar: A selection of shortcuts to perform different actions. The toolbar buttons provide quicker access to a select group of menu bar actions.
status bar: Displays informational messages about the project and the activities of Android Studio together along with the tools menu button located in the left corner.
preview pane: It can be used While editing in the Text view. Within the Preview pane, you can modify the preview by changing various options at the top of the pane, including the preview device, layout theme, platform version and more.
project explorer: It shows the name of my project and in each project it shows the folders for my project. I should see a root project folder, and within it the .idea, gradle, and module folders.
.idea folder: Stores specific metadata by Android Studio.
intellisense: This allows the IDE to determine which values or lines in the code can cause an error. The intellisense then gives a warning as well as hints on how to resolve it.
module: Contains files similar to the usual supplied by Eclipse such as the src, gen, and res folders.
live layout: It allows the developer to view the user interface as the codes are written and modified.
init: creates a new subdirectory named .git that contains all of your necessary repository files or initialize an existing one.
commit: After add command files listed are in the Staging Area, and they are not in our repository yet. To store our staged changes we run the commit command.
push: The push command tells Git where to put our commits.
add: Adds all modified and new (untracked) files in the current directory, thus preparing them to be included in the next git commit.
pull: Helps us to check for changes on our GitHub repository and pull down any new changes.
branch: When we are working on a feature or bug we will often create a copy of our code we can make separate commits to, then when we are done we can merge this branch back into our main master branch.
clone: If you want to get a copy of an existing Git repository the command you need is git clone.
